rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:30–32
rsbNotes.text: 4:30–32 The parable of the mustard seed is again concerned with the kingdom’s present manifestation in the person of Jesus.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:32
rsbNotes.text: 4:32 birds of the air. In Dan. 4:21 the same metaphor refers to the world-wide dominion of Nebuchadnezzar.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:33–34
rsbNotes.text: 4:33, 34 See vv. 10–12.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:35
rsbNotes.text: 4:35 the other side. According to 3:7, Jesus is in Galilee. The “other side” of the lake is the region of the Gadarenes in the Decapolis (5:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:37
rsbNotes.text: 4:37 great windstorm. The Sea of Galilee is about 700 feet below sea level, thirteen miles long and eight miles wide. At its southern end is a deep, cliff-lined valley. The wind funnelling through the surrounding hills and through this valley can whip the lake into sudden violent storms.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:38
rsbNotes.text: 4:38 he was . . . asleep. Jesus had been teaching all day, and was no doubt exhausted. Mark, like John (John 4:6; 11:35, 38), emphasizes the full humanity of Jesus.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 4:39
rsbNotes.text: 4:39 Peace! Be still! Lit. “be muzzled.” Jesus has authority on earth to forgive sins (2:10), He is Lord of the Sabbath (2:28), He has authority in His teaching (1:22) and over the demons (1:27), and now He demonstrates His authority over nature. This calming of the storm resembles His exorcisms; there is the demonic expression of violence (1:26; 5:4, 13), the command to be “silent” (1:25 note), and the resultant calm (5:15). Jesus binds “the strong man” (3:23–27) and reclaims from his power the physical creation.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:1
rsbNotes.text: 5:1 the country of the Gerasenes. Gerasa was thirty miles southeast of the lake. There is also a village named Khersa on the eastern shore with the kind of cliffs and tombs described in the story. Jesus enters the Decapolis, a political association of ten independent Greek city-states, anticipating the future Gentile mission of the church. The Gentile character of the population is apparent since the Jews did not raise pigs, which were unclean under Mosaic law.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:2
rsbNotes.text: 5:2 out of the tombs. This demon-possessed man was exiled from normal human contacts, separated from his village and family (v. 19).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:3
rsbNotes.text: 5:3 no one could bind him. Violence and unusual physical strength leading to slow self-destruction (v. 5; 9:22) often seem to characterize the demon-possessed (v. 13; 1:26; 9:18, 20, 22, 26), but before the spiritual strength of Jesus the demons cower and flee.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:7
rsbNotes.text: 5:7 What have you to do with me. See 1:24.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:9
rsbNotes.text:
5:9 What is your name. Naming someone was believed to be a way of gaining power over them. The demons had already identified Jesus (v. 7; cf. 1:24, 34), but by this question Jesus reveals His superior power.

Legion. Jesus forces the demon to unmask himself. He is not one but many. A Roman legion was six thousand men.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 he begged. The demon cowers before Jesus, even invoking God’s name as a form of protection (v. 7), recognizing that Jesus has absolute power over him.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:13
rsbNotes.text: 5:13 he gave them permission. Jesus permits the demons to enter the pigs, who then hurl themselves over the cliff. This exorcism is a dramatic demonstration of Jesus’ power over evil (vv. 14, 16) and of the presence of the kingdom in His ministry (Luke 11:20). See “Demons” at Deut. 32:17.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:15
rsbNotes.text: 5:15 sitting. In comparison with his previous violent behavior and the recent destruction of the pigs, the man “sitting there, clothed and in his right mind” gives eloquent expression to the peace and life-giving restoration that comes from Jesus’ power (4:39; 9:26, 27).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 5:19
rsbNotes.text: 5:19 Go home. This man becomes the first Gentile missionary. Jesus usually demands silence (1:34 note), but in this instance He allows the preparation for the future mission of the church to begin. Jesus will later command silence regarding a healing performed in the Decapolis, but to no avail (7:31–37).
